rev.comment: /* Golf courses */ rm uncited, but left in the subarticle

Line 108: Line 108:
===Golf courses===
===Golf courses===
Trump currently owns four golf courses in the United States: Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, New York, Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Florida, and Trump National Golf Club in Los Angeles.
Trump currently owns four golf courses in the United States: Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, New York, Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey, Trump International Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Florida, and Trump National Golf Club in Los Angeles.
â
Trump is also building Trump International Golf Club in the Caribbean island of Canouan Island, The Grenadines. The development will include Trump Club Privee, a Monte Carlo inspired casino.{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
 
In 2006 Trump purchased a 1,400-acre (5.7 km2) plot just north of Aberdeen at [[Balmedie#Menie estate|Menie (Balmedie)]], Scotland, with the intention of turning it into a [[Pound sterling|Â£]]1 billion golf resort and "the world's best golf course" capable of hosting world class events such as [[The Open Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_to_build_%C2%A3300m_%22golfing_paradise%22_in_rural_Scotland|title=Donald Trump plans Â£300m "golfing paradise" for rural Scotland|publisher=Wikinews|accessdate=2007-02-20}}</ref> There has been opposition from some locals and negative reaction from environmental groups, but the project continues.
In 2006 Trump purchased a 1,400-acre (5.7 km2) plot just north of Aberdeen at [[Balmedie#Menie estate|Menie (Balmedie)]], Scotland, with the intention of turning it into a [[Pound sterling|Â£]]1 billion golf resort and "the world's best golf course" capable of hosting world class events such as [[The Open Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_to_build_%C2%A3300m_%22golfing_paradise%22_in_rural_Scotland|title=Donald Trump plans Â£300m "golfing paradise" for rural Scotland|publisher=Wikinews|accessdate=2007-02-20}}</ref> There has been opposition from some locals and negative reaction from environmental groups, but the project continues.
